trans-unit.source: Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link> supports continuous deployment to Web Apps from source code control and repository tools like BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, Git, GitHub, Mercurial, and TFS.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link> supports continuous deployment to Web Apps from source code control and repository tools like BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, Git, GitHub, Mercurial, and TFS.

trans-unit.source: You can use these tools to maintain the content and code for your application, and then quickly and easily push changes to your Azure web app when you want.
trans-unit.target: You can use these tools to maintain the content and code for your application, and then quickly and easily push changes to your Azure web app when you want.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you will learn how to use Git to publish directly from your local computer to Web Apps (in Azure, this method of publishing is called Local Git).
trans-unit.target: In this article, you will learn how to use Git to publish directly from your local computer to Web Apps (in Azure, this method of publishing is called Local Git).

trans-unit.source: You will also learn how to enable continuous deployment from repository sites like BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial.
trans-unit.target: You will also learn how to enable continuous deployment from repository sites like BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial.

trans-unit.source: For information about using TFS for continuous deployment, see [Continuous delivery to Azure using Visual Studio Online].
trans-unit.target: For information about using TFS for continuous deployment, see [Continuous delivery to Azure using Visual Studio Online].

trans-unit.source: Many of the Git commands described in this article are performed automatically when creating a web app using the <link><linkText>Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Many of the Git commands described in this article are performed automatically when creating a web app using the <link><linkText>Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Installing Git
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Installing Git

trans-unit.source: The steps required to install Git vary between operating systems.
trans-unit.target: The steps required to install Git vary between operating systems.

trans-unit.source: See [Installing Git] for operating system specific distributions and installation guidance.
trans-unit.target: See [Installing Git] for operating system specific distributions and installation guidance.

trans-unit.source: On some operating systems, both a command-line and GUI version of Git are available.
trans-unit.target: On some operating systems, both a command-line and GUI version of Git are available.

trans-unit.source: The instructions provided in this article use the command-line version.
trans-unit.target: The instructions provided in this article use the command-line version.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 2: Create a local repository
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 2: Create a local repository

trans-unit.source: Perform the following tasks to create a new Git repository.
trans-unit.target: Perform the following tasks to create a new Git repository.

trans-unit.source: Create a directory named MyGitRepository to contain your Git repository and web app files.
trans-unit.target: Create a directory named MyGitRepository to contain your Git repository and web app files.

trans-unit.source: Open a command-line tool, such as GitBash (Windows) or Bash (Unix Shell).
trans-unit.target: Open a command-line tool, such as GitBash (Windows) or Bash (Unix Shell).

trans-unit.source: On OS X systems you can access the command-line through the Terminal application.
trans-unit.target: On OS X systems you can access the command-line through the Terminal application.

trans-unit.source: From the command line, change to the MyGitRepository directory.
trans-unit.target: From the command line, change to the MyGitRepository directory.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to initialize a new Git repository:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to initialize a new Git repository:

trans-unit.source: This should return a message such as Initialized empty Git repository in [path].
trans-unit.target: This should return a message such as Initialized empty Git repository in [path].

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Add a web page
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Add a web page

trans-unit.source: Web Apps supports applications created in a variety of programming languages.
trans-unit.target: Web Apps supports applications created in a variety of programming languages.

trans-unit.source: For this example, you will use a static .html file.
trans-unit.target: For this example, you will use a static .html file.

trans-unit.source: Using a text editor, create a new file named index.html in the root of the Git repository (the MyGitRepository directory that you created earlier).
trans-unit.target: Using a text editor, create a new file named index.html in the root of the Git repository (the MyGitRepository directory that you created earlier).

trans-unit.source: Add the following text as the contents for the index.html file and save it.
trans-unit.target: Add the following text as the contents for the index.html file and save it.

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, verify that you are in the root of your Git repository.
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, verify that you are in the root of your Git repository.

trans-unit.source: Then use the following command to add the index.html file to the repository:
trans-unit.target: Then use the following command to add the index.html file to the repository:

trans-unit.source: You can find help for any git command by typing -help or --help after the command.
trans-unit.target: You can find help for any git command by typing -help or --help after the command.

trans-unit.source: For example, for parameter options for the add command, type 'git add -help' for command-line help or 'git add --help' for more detailed help.
trans-unit.target: For example, for parameter options for the add command, type 'git add -help' for command-line help or 'git add --help' for more detailed help.

trans-unit.source: Next, commit the changes to the repository by using the following command:
trans-unit.target: Next, commit the changes to the repository by using the following command:

trans-unit.source: You should see output similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should see output similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Enable the web app repository
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Enable the web app repository

trans-unit.source: Perform the following steps to enable a Git repository for your web app.
trans-unit.target: Perform the following steps to enable a Git repository for your web app.

trans-unit.source: Log in to the [Azure preview portal].
trans-unit.target: Log in to the [Azure preview portal].

trans-unit.source: In your web app's blade, scroll down to the Deployment section and click Set up continous deployment.
trans-unit.target: In your web app's blade, scroll down to the Deployment section and click Set up continous deployment.

trans-unit.source: Click Choose Source, then click Local Git Repository, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click Choose Source, then click Local Git Repository, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Local Git Repository</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Local Git Repository</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If this is your first time setting up a repository in Azure, you need to create login credentials for it.
trans-unit.target: If this is your first time setting up a repository in Azure, you need to create login credentials for it.

trans-unit.source: You will use them to log into the Azure repository and push changes from your local Git repository.
trans-unit.target: You will use them to log into the Azure repository and push changes from your local Git repository.

trans-unit.source: From your web app's blade, click Settings > Deployment credentials, then configure your deployment username and password.
trans-unit.target: From your web app's blade, click Settings > Deployment credentials, then configure your deployment username and password.

trans-unit.source: When you're done, click OK.
trans-unit.target: When you're done, click OK.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Deploy your project
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Deploy your project

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Pushing local files to Azure (Local Git)</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Pushing local files to Azure (Local Git)</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Deploy files from a repository web site like BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Deploy files from a repository web site like BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Deploy a Visual Studio solution from BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Deploy a Visual Studio solution from BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to publish your web app to Azure using Local Git.
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to publish your web app to Azure using Local Git.

trans-unit.source: In your web app's blade, in the Deployment section, click No deployment found.
trans-unit.target: In your web app's blade, in the Deployment section, click No deployment found.

trans-unit.source: Git URL is the remote reference to deploy to from your local repository.
trans-unit.target: Git URL is the remote reference to deploy to from your local repository.

trans-unit.source: You'll use this URL in the following steps.
trans-unit.target: You'll use this URL in the following steps.

trans-unit.source: Using the command-line, verify that you are in the root of your local Git repository that contains the previously created index.html file.
trans-unit.target: Using the command-line, verify that you are in the root of your local Git repository that contains the previously created index.html file.

trans-unit.source: Use git remote to add the remote reference listed in Git URL from step 1.
trans-unit.target: Use git remote to add the remote reference listed in Git URL from step 1.

trans-unit.source: Your command will look similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: Your command will look similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: The remote command adds a named reference to a remote repository.
trans-unit.target: The remote command adds a named reference to a remote repository.

trans-unit.source: In this example, it creates a reference named 'azure' for your web app's repository.
trans-unit.target: In this example, it creates a reference named 'azure' for your web app's repository.

trans-unit.source: Use the following from the command-line to push the current repository contents from the local repository to the 'azure' remote:
trans-unit.target: Use the following from the command-line to push the current repository contents from the local repository to the 'azure' remote:

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted for the password you created earlier when you reset your deployment credentials in the portal.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted for the password you created earlier when you reset your deployment credentials in the portal.

trans-unit.source: Enter the password (note that Gitbash does not echo asterisks to the console as you type your password).
trans-unit.target: Enter the password (note that Gitbash does not echo asterisks to the console as you type your password).

trans-unit.source: You should see output similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should see output similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: The repository created for your web app expects push requests to target the <html></html>master<html></html> branch of its repository, which will then be used as the content of the web app.
trans-unit.target: The repository created for your web app expects push requests to target the <html></html>master<html></html> branch of its repository, which will then be used as the content of the web app.

trans-unit.source: Go back to your web app's blade in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Go back to your web app's blade in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: No deployment found should be changed to Active Deployment with a log entry of your most recent push.
trans-unit.target: No deployment found should be changed to Active Deployment with a log entry of your most recent push.

trans-unit.source: Click the link under URL at the top of the web app blade to verify that the index.html has been deployed.
trans-unit.target: Click the link under URL at the top of the web app blade to verify that the index.html has been deployed.

trans-unit.source: A page containing 'Hello Git!'
trans-unit.target: A page containing 'Hello Git!'

trans-unit.source: will appear.
trans-unit.target: will appear.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>A webpage containing 'Hello Git!'</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>A webpage containing 'Hello Git!'</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Using a text editor, change the index.html file so that it contains 'Yay!', and then save the file.
trans-unit.target: Using a text editor, change the index.html file so that it contains 'Yay!', and then save the file.

trans-unit.source: Use the following commands from the command-line to add and commit the changes, and then push the changes to the remote repository:
trans-unit.target: Use the following commands from the command-line to add and commit the changes, and then push the changes to the remote repository:

trans-unit.source: Once the push command has completed, refresh the browser (you may have to press Ctrl+F5 for the browser to properly refresh) and note that the content of the page now reflects the latest commit change.
trans-unit.target: Once the push command has completed, refresh the browser (you may have to press Ctrl+F5 for the browser to properly refresh) and note that the content of the page now reflects the latest commit change.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Deploy files from a repository site like BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Deploy files from a repository site like BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial

trans-unit.source: Pushing local files to Azure by using Local Git allows you to manually push updates from a local project to your web app in Azure, while deploying from BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial results in a continuous deployment process where Azure will pull in the most recent updates from your project.
trans-unit.target: Pushing local files to Azure by using Local Git allows you to manually push updates from a local project to your web app in Azure, while deploying from BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial results in a continuous deployment process where Azure will pull in the most recent updates from your project.

trans-unit.source: While both methods result in your project being deployed to Web Apps, continuous deployment is useful when you have multiple people working on a project and want to ensure that the latest version is always published regardless of who made the most recent update.
trans-unit.target: While both methods result in your project being deployed to Web Apps, continuous deployment is useful when you have multiple people working on a project and want to ensure that the latest version is always published regardless of who made the most recent update.

trans-unit.source: Continuous deployment is also useful if you are using one of the above mentioned tools as the central repository for your application.
trans-unit.target: Continuous deployment is also useful if you are using one of the above mentioned tools as the central repository for your application.

trans-unit.source: Deploying files from either GitHub, CodePlex, or BitBucket requires that you have published your local project to one of these services.
trans-unit.target: Deploying files from either GitHub, CodePlex, or BitBucket requires that you have published your local project to one of these services.

trans-unit.source: For more information on publishing your project to these services, see [Create a Repo (GitHub)], [Using Git with CodePlex], [Create a Repo (BitBucket)], [Using Dropbox to Share Git Repositories], or [Quick Start - Mercurial].
trans-unit.target: For more information on publishing your project to these services, see [Create a Repo (GitHub)], [Using Git with CodePlex], [Create a Repo (BitBucket)], [Using Dropbox to Share Git Repositories], or [Quick Start - Mercurial].

trans-unit.source: First put your web app files into the selected repository that will be used for continuous deployment.
trans-unit.target: First put your web app files into the selected repository that will be used for continuous deployment.

trans-unit.source: In your web app's blade in the portal, scroll down to the Deployment section and click Set up continous deployment.
trans-unit.target: In your web app's blade in the portal, scroll down to the Deployment section and click Set up continous deployment.

trans-unit.source: Click Choose Source, then click GitHub, for example.
trans-unit.target: Click Choose Source, then click GitHub, for example.

trans-unit.source: In the Continous Deployment blade, click Authorization, then click Authorize.
trans-unit.target: In the Continous Deployment blade, click Authorization, then click Authorize.

trans-unit.source: The Azure portal will redirect you to the repository site to complete the authorization process.
trans-unit.target: The Azure portal will redirect you to the repository site to complete the authorization process.

trans-unit.source: When you're done, go back to the Azure portal and click OK in the Authorization blade.
trans-unit.target: When you're done, go back to the Azure portal and click OK in the Authorization blade.

trans-unit.source: In the Continous Deployment blade, choose the organization, project, and branch you want to deploy from.
trans-unit.target: In the Continous Deployment blade, choose the organization, project, and branch you want to deploy from.

trans-unit.source: When you're done, click OK.
trans-unit.target: When you're done, click OK.

trans-unit.source: When enabling continuous deployment with GitHub or BitBucket, both public and private projects will be displayed.
trans-unit.target: When enabling continuous deployment with GitHub or BitBucket, both public and private projects will be displayed.

trans-unit.source: Azure creates an association with the selected repository, and pulls in the files from the specified branch.
trans-unit.target: Azure creates an association with the selected repository, and pulls in the files from the specified branch.

trans-unit.source: After this process completes, the Deployment section of your web app's blade will show an Active Deployment message that indicates deployment has succeeded.
trans-unit.target: After this process completes, the Deployment section of your web app's blade will show an Active Deployment message that indicates deployment has succeeded.

trans-unit.source: At this point your project has been deployed from your repository of choice to your web app.
trans-unit.target: At this point your project has been deployed from your repository of choice to your web app.

trans-unit.source: To verify that the web app is active, Click the URL at the top of the portal.
trans-unit.target: To verify that the web app is active, Click the URL at the top of the portal.

trans-unit.source: The browser should navigate to the web app.
trans-unit.target: The browser should navigate to the web app.

trans-unit.source: To verify that continuous deployment is occurring from the repository of your choice, push a change to the repository.
trans-unit.target: To verify that continuous deployment is occurring from the repository of your choice, push a change to the repository.

trans-unit.source: Your web app should update to reflect the changes shortly after the push to the repository completes.
trans-unit.target: Your web app should update to reflect the changes shortly after the push to the repository completes.

trans-unit.source: You can verify that it has pulled in the update in the Deployments blade of your web app.
trans-unit.target: You can verify that it has pulled in the update in the Deployments blade of your web app.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Deploy a Visual Studio solution from BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Deploy a Visual Studio solution from BitBucket, CodePlex, Dropbox, GitHub, or Mercurial

trans-unit.source: Pushing a Visual Studio solution to Web Apps in Azure App Service is just as easy as pushing a simple index.html file.
trans-unit.target: Pushing a Visual Studio solution to Web Apps in Azure App Service is just as easy as pushing a simple index.html file.

trans-unit.source: The Web Apps deployment process streamlines all the details, including restore NuGet dependencies and building the application binaries.
trans-unit.target: The Web Apps deployment process streamlines all the details, including restore NuGet dependencies and building the application binaries.

trans-unit.source: You can follow the source control best practices of maintaining code only in your Git repository, and let Web Apps deployment take care of the rest.
trans-unit.target: You can follow the source control best practices of maintaining code only in your Git repository, and let Web Apps deployment take care of the rest.

trans-unit.source: The steps for pushing your Visual Studio solution to Web Apps is the same as in the <link><linkText>previous section</linkText><title></title></link>, provided that you configure your solution and repository as follows:
trans-unit.target: The steps for pushing your Visual Studio solution to Web Apps is the same as in the <link><linkText>previous section</linkText><title></title></link>, provided that you configure your solution and repository as follows:

trans-unit.source: In your repository root, add a .gitignore file, then specify all files and folders that you want to exclude from your repository, such as the Obj, Bin, and packages folders (see gitignore documentation for formatting information).
trans-unit.target: In your repository root, add a .gitignore file, then specify all files and folders that you want to exclude from your repository, such as the Obj, Bin, and packages folders (see gitignore documentation for formatting information).

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: If you use GitHub, you can optionally generate a Visual Studio specific .gitignore file when you create your repository, which includes all the common temporary files, build results, etc.
trans-unit.target: If you use GitHub, you can optionally generate a Visual Studio specific .gitignore file when you create your repository, which includes all the common temporary files, build results, etc.

trans-unit.source: You can then customize it to suit your specific needs.
trans-unit.target: You can then customize it to suit your specific needs.

trans-unit.source: Add the entire solution's directory tree to your repository, with the .sln file in the repository root.
trans-unit.target: Add the entire solution's directory tree to your repository, with the .sln file in the repository root.

trans-unit.source: In your Visual Studio solution, <link><linkText>enable NuGet Package Restore</linkText><title></title></link> to make Visual Studio automatically restore missing packages.
trans-unit.target: In your Visual Studio solution, <link><linkText>enable NuGet Package Restore</linkText><title></title></link> to make Visual Studio automatically restore missing packages.

trans-unit.source: Once you have set up your repository as described, and configured your web app in Azure for continuous publishing from one of the online Git repositories, you can develop your ASP.NET application locally in Visual Studio and continuously deploy your code simply by pushing your changes to your online Git repository.
trans-unit.target: Once you have set up your repository as described, and configured your web app in Azure for continuous publishing from one of the online Git repositories, you can develop your ASP.NET application locally in Visual Studio and continuously deploy your code simply by pushing your changes to your online Git repository.

trans-unit.source: Disable continuous deployment
trans-unit.target: Disable continuous deployment

trans-unit.source: Continuous deployment can be disabled from the Deployments blade.
trans-unit.target: Continuous deployment can be disabled from the Deployments blade.

trans-unit.source: From your web app's blade, in the Deployment section, click Active Deployment.
trans-unit.target: From your web app's blade, in the Deployment section, click Active Deployment.

trans-unit.source: Then click Disconnect.
trans-unit.target: Then click Disconnect.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>git-DisconnectFromGitHub</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>git-DisconnectFromGitHub</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After answering Yes to the confirmation message, you can return to your web app's blade and click Set up continuous deployment if you would like to set up publishing from another source.
trans-unit.target: After answering Yes to the confirmation message, you can return to your web app's blade and click Set up continuous deployment if you would like to set up publishing from another source.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Troubleshooting
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Troubleshooting

trans-unit.source: The following are errors or problems commonly encountered when using Git to publish to a web app in Azure:
trans-unit.target: The following are errors or problems commonly encountered when using Git to publish to a web app in Azure:

trans-unit.source: Symptom: Unable to access '[siteURL]': Failed to connect to [scmAddress]
trans-unit.target: Symptom: Unable to access '[siteURL]': Failed to connect to [scmAddress]

trans-unit.source: Cause: This error can occur if the web app is not up and running.
trans-unit.target: Cause: This error can occur if the web app is not up and running.

trans-unit.source: Resolution: Start the web app in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Resolution: Start the web app in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Git deployment will not work unless the web app is running.
trans-unit.target: Git deployment will not work unless the web app is running.

trans-unit.source: Symptom: Couldn't resolve host 'hostname'
trans-unit.target: Symptom: Couldn't resolve host 'hostname'

trans-unit.source: Cause: This error can occur if the address information entered when creating the 'azure' remote was incorrect.
trans-unit.target: Cause: This error can occur if the address information entered when creating the 'azure' remote was incorrect.

trans-unit.source: Resolution: Use the git remote -v command to list all remotes, along with the associated URL.
trans-unit.target: Resolution: Use the git remote -v command to list all remotes, along with the associated URL.

trans-unit.source: Verify that the URL for the 'azure' remote is correct.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the URL for the 'azure' remote is correct.

trans-unit.source: If needed, remove and recreate this remote using the correct URL.
trans-unit.target: If needed, remove and recreate this remote using the correct URL.

trans-unit.source: Symptom: No refs in common and none specified; doing nothing.
trans-unit.target: Symptom: No refs in common and none specified; doing nothing.

trans-unit.source: Perhaps you should specify a branch such as 'master'.
trans-unit.target: Perhaps you should specify a branch such as 'master'.

trans-unit.source: Cause: This error can occur if you do not specify a branch when performing a git push operation, and have not set the push.default value used by Git.
trans-unit.target: Cause: This error can occur if you do not specify a branch when performing a git push operation, and have not set the push.default value used by Git.

trans-unit.source: Resolution: Perform the push operation again, specifying the master branch.
trans-unit.target: Resolution: Perform the push operation again, specifying the master branch.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Symptom: src refspec [branchname] does not match any.
trans-unit.target: Symptom: src refspec [branchname] does not match any.

trans-unit.source: Cause: This error can occur if you attempt to push to a branch other than master on the 'azure' remote.
trans-unit.target: Cause: This error can occur if you attempt to push to a branch other than master on the 'azure' remote.

trans-unit.source: Resolution: Perform the push operation again, specifying the master branch.
trans-unit.target: Resolution: Perform the push operation again, specifying the master branch.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Symptom: Error - Changes committed to remote repository but your web app not updated.
trans-unit.target: Symptom: Error - Changes committed to remote repository but your web app not updated.

trans-unit.source: Cause: This error can occur if you are deploying a Node.js application containing a package.json file that specifies additional required modules.
trans-unit.target: Cause: This error can occur if you are deploying a Node.js application containing a package.json file that specifies additional required modules.

trans-unit.source: Resolution: Additional messages containing 'npm ERR!'
trans-unit.target: Resolution: Additional messages containing 'npm ERR!'

trans-unit.source: should be logged prior to this error, and can provide additional context on the failure.
trans-unit.target: should be logged prior to this error, and can provide additional context on the failure.

trans-unit.source: The following are known causes of this error and the corresponding 'npm ERR!'
trans-unit.target: The following are known causes of this error and the corresponding 'npm ERR!'

trans-unit.source: message:
trans-unit.target: message:

trans-unit.source: Malformed package.json file: npm ERR!
trans-unit.target: Malformed package.json file: npm ERR!

trans-unit.source: Couldn't read dependencies.
trans-unit.target: Couldn't read dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Native module that does not have a binary distribution for Windows:
trans-unit.target: Native module that does not have a binary distribution for Windows:

trans-unit.source: npm ERR!
trans-unit.target: npm ERR!

trans-unit.source: \`cmd "/c" "node-gyp rebuild"\` failed with 1
trans-unit.target: \`cmd "/c" "node-gyp rebuild"\` failed with 1

trans-unit.source: npm ERR!
trans-unit.target: npm ERR!

trans-unit.source: [modulename@version] preinstall: \`make || gmake\`
trans-unit.target: [modulename@version] preinstall: \`make || gmake\`

trans-unit.source: Additional Resources
trans-unit.target: Additional Resources

trans-unit.source: [How to use PowerShell for Azure]
trans-unit.target: [How to use PowerShell for Azure]

trans-unit.source: [How to use the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux]
trans-unit.target: [How to use the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux]

trans-unit.source: [Git Documentation]
trans-unit.target: [Git Documentation]

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Project Kudu</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Project Kudu</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.
